attributes.comment:
I write to express grave concern over the steep increases in immigration
application fees proposed last week by U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
(USCIS). The National Immigrant Justice Center and the International Refugee
Center, both partners of Heartland Alliance, work with thousands of immigrants,
refugees, and asylees annually to provide a range of legal and refugee
resettlement services.
I am particularly troubled by the proposed increase of two fees: the fee to
naturalize, and the fee to adjust to lawful permanent residence, commonly known
as the status that earns an immigrant a ?green card?. Both will be raised at
shockingly high rates and will negatively affect tens of thousands of low-income
immigrants and asylees each year.
USCIS proposed to raise the naturalization fee from $330 to $595. This increase
will make citizenship cost-prohibitive for thousands of longtime permanent
residents who have worked and raised families in the United States and who want
to assume the responsibilities, rights, and protections afforded to citizens under
the U.S. Constitution.
In addition, the proposed hike in the fee to adjust status to permanent residence
will be insurmountable for many asylees. By law, those who apply for and obtain
asylum within the U.S. must apply to adjust their status and obtain a green card
within a year of the grant of asylum. These asylees are fortunate to have the
opportunity to live in safety in America, but they also face significant hurdles.
Many struggle to support their families, learn English, and secure social services.
Unlike refugees, they are not exempt from the fee for a green card application.
Now, USCIS proposes to raise that fee from $325 to $905. These fees are
assigned to each individual applicant, such that under the proposed rule, a family
of four will have to pay an exorbitant $3,620 within a year of the asylum grant.
Furthermore, while fee waivers remain available to certain naturalization applicants,
the proposed rule removes green card applicants from eligibility for fee waivers
altogether. This change will harm not only the asylees discussed above, but also
immigrants who originally obtained special immigration status as victims of
trafficking or domestic violence, and who face similar challenges to building stable
lives in America. For policy reasons we all support, these vulnerable immigrants
are either exempt from fees or eligible for fee waivers when they initially apply for
lawful immigration status. Under the proposed rule, however, when these
individuals apply for green cards soon after, they will be ineligible for a fee waiver.
The director of USCIS, Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security Emilio
Gonzalez, contends that the agency must operate on a business model, and
therefore income from fees must offset virtually all of the agency's costs.
Accordingly, Assistant Secretary Gonzalez stated that the agency will not seek
funds from Congress to reduce the unreasonable burden of the fee increases on
immigrants and asylees.
Even without the proposed increase, the fee to apply for citizenship has already
increased fourfold in the past eight years. Every immigrant expects to pay a fee for
a benefit, but those fees must be fair.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Peter Gunther
